column1: Weißwasser is the third largest town in the Görlitz district after Görlitz and Zittau. The town's landmark is its water tower. The town is part of the recognized Sorbian settlement area in Saxony. Upper Sorbian has an official status next to German
column2: all villages bear names in both languages.

column1: Weißwasser was mentioned for the first time on 8 June 1552
column2: when it was part of the Czech (Bohemian) Crown Lands. The town's name means "white water". In 1635 it passed to the Electorate of Saxony
column3: also ruled in personal union with the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth between 1697 and 1763
column5: in 1815 it was annexed by Prussia and included within the Province of Silesia. In the 19th and 20th centuries
column6: Weißwasser was the European centre of glass production. It became part of the Prussian Province of Lower Silesia in 1919.

column1: Weißwasser received its town charter on 28 August 1935. During World War II
column2: the Germans established and operated the FAL Weisswasser subcamp of the Gross-Rosen concentration camp
column3: whose prisoners were mainly Jewish women. In the Second World War
column4: 40% of the town was destroyed. With the dissolution of Prussia resulting from the war
column5: the town became part of Saxony from 1945–52. It was then part of communist East Germany from 1952–90 and administered within Bezirk Cottbus. Many enterprises had to close during the communist regime. After the fall of the Berlin Wall
column6: only a few enterprises were left. It was included within a restored Saxony after German reunification.

column1: Weißwasser now struggles with the after-effects of German reunification
column2: as the fall of the Berlin Wall has had a devastating effect on the local economy. Many people have since lost their jobs and the town's population continues to suffers from a high percentage of unemployment. Consequently
column3: many have left the area in the hope of finding a new job elsewhere in a reunited Germany.
